In an effort to get the Core tools working again, Jeff kindly volunteered to
head up this task. Work will be done in stages:

1). Fix-up 
  - make the current core tools work against the current 3.0 code base. 
  - set our plugin.xml to be <?eclipse=3.0. 
  - migrate old extensions to newly named UI points, etc.

2). RCP 
  - make sure that we can be run in the RCP world. 
  - split up the tools so we don't rely on runtime.compatibility. 
  - separate runtime/runtime registry/resources?

3). New work 
  - Geoff's marker spy
  - new OSGi bundle spies
  - add new views, etc

Goal is to have #1 and #2 done in the next 2 weeks.

Created an attachment (id=10128)
preference viewer

Here's a preference viewer for the new eclipse preferences. Its basic...just
shows the tree. Some parts are slow since it agressively loads all nodes at
each level. Should probably add a "collapse all" button too.

Preferences viewer looks cool.  I never knew there was so much stuffed in 
preferences.  :-o  I'm not sure what the empty nodes mean -- defaults are 
set?  Will this be explained in the online docs?

BTW, is the dependency on the compatibility plug-in necessary?

Empty nodes means that someone asked for it. (they are lazily initialized) The
reason that the default has a child (mostly empty) for each bundle in the system
was a design decision. Since they are not persisted to disk, what are the
children of the "/default" node? I decided that they should be the bundles which
are installed on the system since any bundle can customize their preferences. 

With the "/instance" it was more straight forward...just see who has prefs
stored on disk.

The compatibility layer thing was just an artifact of the way I created the
plug-in. I've removed it and it still works ok.

Created an attachment (id=29377)
Patch for MarkerSpy

I have a patch for MarkerSpy that:

a) Makes the spy play nice with the malleable Extension registry (registers an
IExtensionChangeHandler to listen for changes).

b) adds a context menu action to the view that allows one to delete the
selected markers in the View. (Added as some to-remain-unnamed 3rd party
plugins are not very good at removing thier markers - ever).
Released the MarkerSpy changes to HEAD. Thanks Geoff.
